questions.title: Passage I
questions.article:
Fin whales engulf and filter massive amounts of water and prey during an event called lunge feeding. The 5 distinct stages of a lunge-feeding event are listed and described below.

·Stage 1: Rapid acceleration of the whale

·Stage 2: Mouth opening and engulfment

·Stage 3: Onset of mouth closure

·Stage 4: Continued mouth closure and pre-purging

·Stage 5: Purging (filtering water from prey)

The figure below shows how a fin whale's speed and gape angle (angle between the top and the bottom of the fin whale's mouth) varied during a lunge-feeding event.


Figure adapted from J.Potvin et al., “Passive Versus Active Engulfment: Verdict from Trajectory Simulations of Lunge-Feeding Fin Whales Balaenoptera physalus."©2009 by The Royal Society.
questions.question: 1. Over which of the following time periods of the lunge-feeding event did the gape angle both increase and decrease ？

questions.title: Passage I
questions.article:
Fin whales engulf and filter massive amounts of water and prey during an event called lunge feeding. The 5 distinct stages of a lunge-feeding event are listed and described below.

·Stage 1: Rapid acceleration of the whale

·Stage 2: Mouth opening and engulfment

·Stage 3: Onset of mouth closure

·Stage 4: Continued mouth closure and pre-purging

·Stage 5: Purging (filtering water from prey)

The figure below shows how a fin whale's speed and gape angle (angle between the top and the bottom of the fin whale's mouth) varied during a lunge-feeding event.


Figure adapted from J.Potvin et al., “Passive Versus Active Engulfment: Verdict from Trajectory Simulations of Lunge-Feeding Fin Whales Balaenoptera physalus."©2009 by The Royal Society.
questions.question: 2. The figure indicates that at Stage 3 of the lunge-feeding event, the fin whale was:

choices.A: moving at its greatest speed and had just opened its mouth to begin engulfment.
choices.B: moving at its greatest speed and had just closed its mouth to begin purging.
choices.C: slowing down, and the whale’s gape angle was at its greatest value.
choices.D: speeding up, and the whale’s gape angle was at its smallest value.

questions.question: 4. During the lunge-feeding event, how much time elapsed from the start of mouth opening to the end of mouth closure?

questions.question: 5. Among the following times during Stage 1 of the lunge-feeding event, at which time did the fin whale have the greatest amount of momentum?

questions.question: 6. Which of the following statements best explains why the speed of the fin whale decreased during Stage 2? During Stage 2, the cross-sectional area of the whale’s mouth was:

choices.A: increasing, which caused the opposing drag force on the whale to decrease.
choices.B: increasing, which caused the opposing drag force on the whale to increase.
choices.C: decreasing, which caused the opposing drag force on the whale to decrease,
choices.D: decreasing, which caused the opposing drag force on the whale to increase.

questions.title: Passage II
questions.article: Figure 1 shows a model of an amusement park ride. At time = 0 sec, the cart is released from rest at Point P. It descends the tower toward Point Q and strikes the spring. As the spring is compressed, it slows the carts descent and eventually rebounds, sending the cart back up the tower. Frictional forces act on the cart whenever it is in motion, and the spring never extends above Point Q. Figure 2 shows computer simulations of the cart's height (the distance from ground level to the bottom of the cart), its velocity, and its acceleration during the first 20 sec of motion.
questions.question: 7. At approximately what time(s) during the 20 sec period, if any, does the cart touch the ground?

choices.D: At no time does the cart touch the ground

questions.title: Passage III
questions.article:
Southern pine beetles (SPBs) construct nursery galleries for their larvae within the bark of pine trees. SPBs introduce Fungus M into the nursery gallery to serve as a food source for developing SPB larvae. If a competitor fungus——Fungus A——outcompetes Fungus M in the gallery, SPB larval development will be disrupted.

SPBs also introduce into the nursery gallery a bacterial species that is thought to help maintain the relationship between SPBs and Fungus M. Two strains of this bacterial species, Strain W and Strain R, have been isolated from SPBs. Scientists did 2 experiments to study whether the introduction of Strain W or Strain R would be more likely to protect the larval food supply.

Experiment 1

An agar growth medium contained in each of 160 petri dishes was inoculated at its center with Strain W. The medium in each dish was also inoculated, at a point near its edge, with a fungal species: in 80 dishes with Fungus M and in the other 80 dishes with Fungus A. At the end of weeks, the shortest distance across the zone of inhibition (ZOI: the space between the edges of fungal growth and of bacterial growth) was measured for each dish. The shortest distance for a dish, defined here as the width of the ZOI, determined the degree of inhibition exhibited by the dish (see Table 1).


Figure 1 shows, for each fungus, what percent of the 80 dishes exhibited a given degree of inhibition.


Experiment 2

Experiment 1 was repeated, except with Strain R instead of Strain W (see Figure 2).
questions.question: 13. Which of the following statements describes a difference between Experiments 1 and 2?

choices.A: A different bacterial strain was tested in Experiment 1 than was tested in Experiment 2.
choices.B: A different fungal species was tested in Experiment 1 than was tested in Experiment 2.
choices.C: SPB larvae were observed in Experiment 1 but not in Experiment 2.
choices.D: SPB larvae were observed in Experiment 2 but not in Experiment 1.

questions.question: 14. The type of agar growth medium used in Experiments 1 and 2 was most likely chosen for which of the following reasons?

choices.A: Only bacteria grow on this type of medium.
choices.B: Only fungi grow on this type of medium.
choices.C: Both bacteria and fungi grow on this type of medium.
choices.D: Neither bacteria nor fungi grow on this type of medium.

questions.question: 15. Consider the petri dishes containing Strain R and Fungus M. What percent of those dishes exhibited a mild degree of inhibition?

questions.question: 18. Based on the results of Experiment 2, the introduction of Strain R into a nursery gallery by SPBs would more likely strongly inhibit the growth of which fungus, Fungus M or Fungus A?

choices.A: Fungus M, because approximately 27% of the petri dishes containing Strain R and Fungus M exhibited a strong degree of inhibition.
choices.B: Fungus M, because approximately 71% of the petri dishes containing Strain R and Fungus M exhibited a strong degree of inhibition.
choices.C: Fungus A, because approximately 52% of the petri dishes containing Strain R and Fungus A exhibited a strong degree of inhibition.
choices.D: Fungus A, because approximately 87% of the petri dishes containing Strain R and Fungus A exhibited a strong degree of inhibition.

questions.question: 19. Which of the following figures best depicts each of 80 of the petri dishes in Experiment 1 immediately following inoculation?

questions.title: Passage IV
questions.article:
A transformer is an electrical component used to increase or decrease voltage. In 3 experiments, a group of students studied transformers using the setup shown in Figure 1.


An input coil was wrapped Nin turns around one side of a core (a solid ring) and then connected to an ammeter (current-measuring device) and a power source. An output coil was wrapped Nout turns around the opposite side of the core and then connected to an ammeter and a voltmeter. Uin and Uout were the input and output voltages (in volts, V), respectively. Iin and Iout were the input and output currents (in milliamperes, mA), respectively.

Experiment 1

In Trials 1-12, the core was made of iron, and the power source was a generator of alternating current (AC; current that varies over time). The students measured Iin, Uout, and Iout for various combinations of Nin, Nout, and Uin (see Table 1).


Experiment 2

In Trials 13-17, the procedure followed in Trial 5 was repeated except that the core material was varied (see Table 2).


Experiment 3

The procedures followed in Trials 1-12 were repeated, except that the power source was a battery supplying direct current (DC; current that remains constant over time). The Iin results matched those of Experiment 1, but in every trial, Uout was 0 V and Iout was 0 mA.
questions.question: 20. One of the students concluded that as Uin increases, Iin also increases. The student most likely arrived at this conclusion based on the results of which of the following groups of trials?

questions.question: 21. If Nin had been 300 turns in Trail 4, Uout would most likely have been:

questions.question: 24. For a transformer like those tested in Experiments 1-3 to generate an output voltage, a phenomenon called induction must occur in the core. Based on the results of Experiments 1 and 3, induction occurred only in the trials with:

choices.A: an AC power source, because the transformers tested in Experiment 1 generated an output voltage, but those tested in Experiment 3 did not.
choices.B: an AC power source, because the transformers tested in Experiment 3 generated an output voltage,” but those tested in Experiment 1 did not.
choices.C: a DC power source, because the transformers tested in Experiment 1 generated an output voltage, but those tested in Experiment 3 did not.
choices.D: a DC power source, because the transformers tested in Experiment 3 generated an output voltage, but those tested in Experiment 1 did not.

In Trials 13-17, the procedure followed in Trial 5 was repeated except that the core material was varied (see Table 2).

The procedures followed in Trials 1-12 were repeated, except that the power source was a battery supplying direct current (DC; current that remains constant over time). The Iin results matched those of Experiment 1, but in every trial, Uout was 0 V and Iout was 0 mA.
questions.question: 25. In Experiments 1-3, there was no trial performed with a:

choices.A: metal core and an AC power supply.
choices.B: metal core and a DC power supply.
choices.C: nonmetal core and an AC power supply.
choices.D: nonmetal core and a DC power supply.

questions.title: Passage IV
questions.article:
A transformer is an electrical component used to increase or decrease voltage. In 3 experiments, a group of students studied transformers using the setup shown in Figure 1.


An input coil was wrapped Nin turns around one side of a core (a solid ring) and then connected to an ammeter (current-measuring device) and a power source. An output coil was wrapped Nout turns around the opposite side of the core and then connected to an ammeter and a voltmeter. Uin and Uout were the input and output voltages (in volts, V), respectively. Iin and Iout were the input and output currents (in milliamperes, mA), respectively.

Experiment 1

In Trials 1-12, the core was made of iron, and the power source was a generator of alternating current (AC; current that varies over time). The students measured Iin, Uout, and Iout for various combinations of Nin, Nout, and Uin (see Table 1).


Experiment 2

In Trials 13-17, the procedure followed in Trial 5 was repeated except that the core material was varied (see Table 2).


Experiment 3

The procedures followed in Trials 1-12 were repeated, except that the power source was a battery supplying direct current (DC; current that remains constant over time). The Iin results matched those of Experiment 1, but in every trial, Uout was 0 V and Iout was 0 mA.
questions.question: 26. In Trials 13-17, the values of Nin, Nout, and Uin were, respectively:

questions.title: Passage V
questions.article:
Two scientists discuss whether a snowball Earth (Earth completely covered with glacial ice) existed from 710 million years ago (mya) to 700 mya, a period during which ail the continents were located on or near the equator.

Scientist 1

A million years before 710 mya, glacial ice covered all of Earth's surface except the low latitudes (30°N to 30°S). Over the next million years, continuing rapid rock weathering in the low latitudes removed CO2 from the atmosphere, and the ice at high latitudes reflected incoming solar radiation. Both processes cooled Earth, which allowed the ice to spread and cover the remainder of Earth 's surface by 710 mya. Soon thereafter, the 1-kilometer-thick ice cover caused the extinction of al photosynthetic organisms. Sediments deposited at the low latitudes by glaciers during the period from 710 mya to 700 mya have been found.

Banded iron formations (BIFs) that formed in the million years after 700 mya at the low latitudes have been found. The BIFs formed only in ocean water that was saturated with Fe2+, an ion of iron that reacts readily with atmospheric O2. Saturation with Fe2+ was possible only if an ocean had been cut off from atmospheric O2 for millions of years by thick ice. Once the ice melted, the Fe2+ reacted with O2 to form BIFs.

Scientist 2

From 710 mya to 700 mya glacial ice covered all of Earth's surface except the low latitudes. The low latitudes remained mostly ice-free over this period because the continents there absorbed enough solar radiation to keep the average temperature above 0°C. Although rapid rock weathering was removing CO2 from the atmosphere, wide spread, continual volcanic eruptions at low latitudes simultaneously added an equal amount of CO2 to the atmosphere.

Fossils of photosynthetic organisms from this period have been found. Some of the sediments from this period were deposited at low latitudes when floating icebergs that broke off of glaciers at high latitudes melted and dropped sediment that had been trapped in the ice. BIFs did form as described by Scientist 1, but only in the few isolated ocean basins at low latitudes that had been completely covered with thick ice over this period.
questions.question: 27. BIFs are composed primarily of the mineral hematite (Fe2O3). Based on Scientist 1’s discussion of the formation of BIFs, which of the following expressions best represents the formation of the hematite in BIFs?

questions.question: 28. Which of the following processes is discussed by Scientist 2 but not by Scientist 1 ?

choices.A: The removal of CO2 from the atmosphere by rock weathering
choices.B: The addition of CO2 to the atmosphere by volcanoes

questions.question: 29. Assume that from 710 mya to 700 mya, rock weathering was the only process removing CO2 from the atmosphere and volcanic eruption was the only process adding CO2 to the atmosphere. Based on Scientist 2’s discussion, which of the following graphs best represents the CO2 concentration in the atmosphere over this period?

questions.question: 30. Fossils of the photosynthetic organisms mentioned by Scientist 2 would most likely have been found from 710 mya to 700 mya in areas at which of the following latitudes?

questions.question: 31. Suppose it were discovered that air temperatures everywhere on Earth were continuously at or below -10℃ from 710 mya to 700 mya. This discovery would more strongly support the viewpoint of which scientist?

choices.A: Scientist 1, because that temperature is well above the maximum temperature at which glacial ice can form.
choices.B: Scientist 1, because that temperature is well below the maximum temperature at which glacial ice can form.
choices.C: Scientist 2, because that temperature is well above the maximum temperature at which glacial ice can form.
choices.D: Scientist 2, because that temperature is well below the maximum temperature at which glacial ice can form.

questions.question: 32. Suppose it were discovered that no O2 had been present in Earth's atmosphere from 700 mya to 690 mya. Would the viewpoint of Scientist 1 be strengthened or weakened by this discovery?

choices.A: Strengthened, because it would indicate that BIFs would have formed at low latitudes during that period.
choices.B: Strengthened, because it would indicate that BIFs would not have formed at low latitudes during that period.
choices.C: Weakened, because it would indicate that BIFs would have formed at low latitudes during that period.
choices.D: Weakened, because it would indicate that BIFs would not have formed at low latitudes during that period.

questions.question: 33. Suppose it were discovered that most of Earth’s surface between 30°N and 60°N latitude was ice-free 705 mya. This discovery would contradict one or more statements made by which of the scientists, if either?

questions.title: Passage VI
questions.article:
The ideal gas law (IGL) describes the physical behavior of gases. Although ideal gases do not exist, the IGL is a useful model for many real gases. A researcher used the IGL to predict trends in the pressure of an ideal gas under various sets of conditions. Then, the researcher performed 3 experiments to compare the IGL predictions with trends in the pressure of each of 2 real gases (Gas Y and Gas Z) under the same sets of conditions. The conditions that were varied for an ideal gas, for Gas Y, and for Gas Z were the following:

·The gas temperature, T (in kelvins, K)

·The amount of gas, n (in moles, mol; 1 mol=6.0 x 1023 atoms or molecules), in a container

·The volume of the container, V (in liters, L)

Experiment 1

The pressure, P (in megapascals, MPa), of an n=1 mol sample of Gas Y in a 1.0 L container was recorded for values of T from 200 K to 450 K. This procedure was repeated for Gas Z. Figure 1 shows the trends for the 2 gases. Also shown is the trend predicted by the IGL.


Experiment 2

The pressure, P, of a sample of Gas Y in a 1.0 L container was recorded for values of n from 1 mol to 10 mol, while T was held constant at 400 K. This procedure was repeated for Gas Z. Figure 2 shows the trends for the 2 gases and the trend predicted by the IGL.


Experiment 3

The pressure, P, of an n=1 mol sample of Gas Y in a container of adjustable volume was recorded for values of V from 0.5 L to 1.0 L. while T was held constant at 400 K. This procedure was repeated for Gas Z. Figure 3 shows the trends for the 2 gases and the trend predicted by the IGL.
questions.question: 34. In which experiments was T held constant?

questions.title: Passage VI
questions.article:

questions.question: 35. The purpose of Experiment 2 was most likely to determine the relationship between:

choices.A: P and T while holding n and V constant.
choices.B: P and n while holding T and V constant.
choices.C: n and T while holding V and P constant.
choices.D: n and V while holding P and T constant.

questions.question: 36. Based on the results of Experiments 1-3, which gas exhibited behaviors more like those that were predicted by the IGL ?

choices.A: Gas Y, because values of P for Gas Y deviated more from the IGL predictions than did values of P for Gas Z.
choices.B: Gas Y, because values of P for Gas Y deviated less from the IGL predictions than did values of P for Gas Z.
choices.C: Gas Z, because values of P for Gas Z deviated more from the IGL predictions than did values of P for Gas Y.
choices.D: Gas Z, because values of P for Gas Z deviated less from the IGL predictions than did values of P for Gas Y.

questions.question: 37. In Experiment 1, was the average kinetic energy of Gas Y molecules more likely greater at P = 2.0 MPa or at P = 4.0 MPa ?

choices.A: At P = 2.0 MPa, because at that lower pressure, the gas molecules had less room in which to move.
choices.B: At P = 2.0 MPa, because the average kinetic energy of a gas increases as T decreases.
choices.C: At P = 4.0 MPa, because at that higher pressure, the gas molecules had more room in which to move.
choices.D: At P = 4.0 MPa, because the average kinetic energy of a gas increases as T increases.

questions.question: 38. The containers used in Experiments 1-3 could withstand the same maximum pressure. Based on the results of the experiments, that maximum pressure must have been closest to which of the following?

questions.question: 39. One mole of Gas Y has a mass of 20 g. In Experiment 2, what was the mass of the Gas Y sample when the pressure of the sample was 25 MPa ?

The conditions that were varied for an ideal gas, for Gas Y, and for Gas Z were the following:

·The gas temperature, T (in kelvins, K)

·The amount of gas, n (in moles, mol; 1 mol=6.0 x 1023 atoms or molecules), in a container

·The volume of the container, V (in liters, L)

Experiment 1

The pressure, P (in megapascals, MPa), of an n=1 mol sample of Gas Y in a 1.0 L container was recorded for values of T from 200 K to 450 K. This procedure was repeated for Gas Z. Figure 1 shows the trends for the 2 gases. Also shown is the trend predicted by the IGL.


Experiment 2

The pressure, P, of a sample of Gas Y in a 1.0 L container was recorded for values of n from 1 mol to 10 mol, while T was held constant at 400 K. This procedure was repeated for Gas Z. Figure 2 shows the trends for the 2 gases and the trend predicted by the IGL.


Experiment 3

The pressure, P, of an n=1 mol sample of Gas Y in a container of adjustable volume was recorded for values of V from 0.5 L to 1.0 L. while T was held constant at 400 K. This procedure was repeated for Gas Z. Figure 3 shows the trends for the 2 gases and the trend predicted by the IGL.
questions.question: 40. Consider an n = 1 mol sample of Gas Z at 400 K in a 1.0 L container of adjustable volume. Suppose the researcher must decrease the container’s volume, but wishes to hold P constant. Based on the results of Experiments 1-3, which of the following additional actions should the researcher perform simultaneously as V is decreased?

choices.A: Decrease T while holding n constant
choices.B: Increase T while holding n constant
choices.C: Hold both T and n constant
